San Fernando Pampanga

Swipe

Culture

The beauty of City of San Fernando Pampanga goes deep to its ability to preserve culture and heritage while securing development. It is a major tourism service center known for its grand yearly events that showcase its unique traditions, culinary delicacies, and craftmanship.

In this section, the exclusive festivals and culture known in San Fernando will be explained. Click the images from each containers to reveal more details.

Giant Lantern Festival
Robinsons Starmills

San Fernando Pampanga is known as the Christmas Capital of the Philippines. The Giant Lantern Festival attracts thousands of locals and tourists who wish to witness the dazzling sets of lights. The interplay of local materials such as capiz and modern elements like fiberglass are infused to create intricate designs. These lanterns are truly a manifestation of the local barangay's craftmaship.

San Fernando’s “Apung Gari Bakery & Kiosk” established in 1955 by couple Jesusa “Susing” Quiambao and husband Jose “Pitong” Valencia. The name came from Susing’s mother, Magarita Quiambao known by managing the “La Satisfacion Bakery, Apung Gari.
San Fernando

Pyestang Fernandino
San Fernando

The main celebration of this city is the city fiesta itself. Every 30th of May Fernandinos gather to celebrate the town’s fiesta in honor of St. Ferdinand, the namesake of the town. It is commemorated the Filipino way by a succession of masses and a grand procession. Never straying away from food, native Filipino cuisine is served during this festival as well as Kapampangan goods that really define the province.

San Fernando is known for their “Parul”. The industry owes its popularity to them who pioneered the evolution of this paper / wooden star lanterns for the “lubenes” (procession) to the giant kaleidoscopic lanterns which are present every December’s Giant Lantern Festival.
San Fernando

Sinukwan Festival
Pampanga Provincial Capitol

The Sinukwan Festival is believed to be an old tradition but there has been no accurate date or year to which it was founded. However, it has been celebrated throughout the years and made a big impact on the people’s culture that they happily celebrate it every year. The Sinukwan represents and honors King Sinukwan or what locals would call, “Aring Sinukwan”. He is an Ancient Kapampangan God which the town’s people honors by street dancing which is actually one of the main highlights or the main activities during the 7th day event period.

Kapampangan’s have been creating all kinds of arts and crafts with their hands for the purposes of utilitarian and decorative functions (homes, word, leisure and religion). To name a few: Kuran at Pasu (Sto. Tomas), Gitara (Guagua), Burarul (Angeles), etc.
San Fernando

Lenten Rites
San Pedro Cutud

The Cutud Lenten Rites is a re-enactment of the passion, suffering and death of Jesus Christ held in Barangay San Pedro Cutud in the City of San Fernando, Pampanga every Good Friday. The staging of the Via Crucis or Way of the Cross can be traced back in 1955, which was performed back then by amateur volunteer artists of the village.

Pyestang Tugak
Robinsons Starmills

Dating back its origin, during the start of the rains, as the town folks would start planting rice; children would set out for the rice fields, streams and estuaries fed by the Rio Grande de Pampanga. This signaled the start of the frog-catching and rainy season eventually became a frog-catching season. Catching frogs was relatively easy. With fishing rod and string, the children jiggled a black piece of cloth in mid-air to simulate flies. As the frogs jumped and swallowed the cloth, they were quickly placed in reed containers or sacks to be dressed later with ash to remove their slime. Betute, as the same sounds, is a pun for betute (pufferfish), a term used to stuffed with a sausage meat or mincemeat. This actually ushered the start of Kapampangan Frog Tradition.


One of the strengths of Kapampangan people is cooking. Pampanga is known as the Culinary Capital of the Philippines. One of the well-known dish in Pampanga is Sisig, usually is made from parts of pig head and chicken liver, it is seasoned with calamansi or lime, onions and chili peppers. Angeles City's Sisig Fiesta will feature the Philippines' best pork dish. SISIG, named the “arguably greatest pork dish on earth” by the New York Times, debuted last April and April 28, 2018 at the Train Station ‘Crossing' in Angeles City. Kapampangan loves celebrations. They have a lot of festivals like Hot Air Balloon competitions, aircraft maneuvers and precision flying, ultralights, RC Demonstration Flying, sky diving, aircraft rally, rocketeering, flag hop, balloon bursting competition, kite flying, trade fair, carnival rides, and nightly concerts are all part of the annual festival. Thousands of visitors come to the site to see the early morning and late afternoon balloon fly-outs, which include foreign hot-air balloons from all over the world. Another is the Giant Lantern Festival held every December of the year, the star lantern parol is perhaps the most iconic Filipino Christmas emblem – bright, lovingly made, and brimming with the spirit of the season. The Christmas lantern, or Parul Sampernandu in Kapampangan, is inextricably linked to the city that gave birth to it, San Fernando. San Fernando is well-known for it. It is this that has made the city popular throughout the region, if not the entire world. And San Fernando has earned for itself the title of “Christmas Capital of the Philippines.” And lastly, there were hundreds of visitors watched in disbelief as actors disguised as Roman soldiers pounded four-inch nails into a Filipino's hands and feet into a wooden cross for the 33rd time in a Good Friday crucifixion re-enactment. Kapampangan’s are known to be deeply religious. Most are devout Catholics, thus they take their religiosity to the extreme sometimes. One of such actions happens in the City of San Fernando Pampanga, Barangay San Pedro Cutud. The San Pedro Cutud Lenten Rites is a Holy Week (Good Friday) re-enactment of Christ’s Passion and Death where it includes a passion play where at least three penitents are nailed to wooden crosses atop a makeshift Calvary though this practice is not recommended by religious leaders in the country the is still attended routinely by many Catholics all over the world. Year after year, visitors flock to the province of Pampanga, north of the capital, to see the gruesome show of devotion, which is frowned upon by the Roman Catholic Church in the Philippines. Barefoot penitents often whip themselves as a form of penance.

Destinations and Toponyms

The City of San Fernando has some of the most important places to visit in Pampanga. The City is only a 2-3 hour drive from Metro Manila and it makes a great setting for a bonding during the weekend, minus the hassle of traveling for too long. From heritage sites to enormous amusment park, The City of San Fernando is worth stopping by. If you’re still planning out your itinerary, read on to find out about the best places to visit in San Fernando, Pampanga

In this section, the toponyms and destinations known in San Fernando will be explained. Click the images from each containers to reveal more details.

Skyranch
A visit to the Sky Ranch will surely make you feel like a child again. Located just behind SM City San Fernando in San Fernando, Pampanga, the park has 23 rides you can choose from—the Pampanga Eye, Drop Tower, Super Viking, Loop Roller Coaster, Bungee Jump, Space Shuttle, and more. The park does not have an entrance fee, but you have to pay to get on each of the rides.
Heritage Houses
The heritage district will save you a spot to get a glimpse of the past. Much like Vigan in Ilocos Sur, San Fernando, Pampanga boasts of its own Heritage District which include heritage churches, buildings, schools and houses. The heritage district defines the lives of old and current Fernandinos and the district can all be traveled on foot.
Pampanga Provincial Capitol
The original building was constructed shortly after the provincial capital of Pampanga was transferred from Bacolor to San Fernando in 1904. Annexes were added before the war. It was the site of a major battle between the Philippine Commonwealth troops and local guerrilla forces and the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II.
San Fernando Train Station
Inaugurated in 1892 by Manila Railroad Company. Jose Rizal disembarked from this station to visit his friends in San Fernando to recruit members of the La Liga Filipina. During the Death March in April 1942, it was the ending point of the long walk from Bataan of the Filipino and American prisoners of war.
Metropolitan Cathedral
President Emilio Aguinaldo and his cabinet viewed the Philippine Revolutionary Army from the windows of convent in 1898. The church and convent were burned by the Philippine Revolutionary Army on orders of Gen. Antonio Luna in 1899. It was again destroyed by a big fire in 1939 and later restored by Architech Fernando Ocampo.
McDonald's Capital Town
McDonald’s just opened its largest store in the country to date and it's located in San Fernando, Pampanga. The two-level outlet located inside The Capital Town boasts more than 1,000 square meters of floor area, making it the biggest in the Philippines. The store features a modern McCafe, an expansive parking area, a green wall, and McDo Park.

Toponyms

The City of San Fernando is named after King Ferdinand VI of Spain and placed under the patronage of Saint Ferdinand III of Castile and Leon, whose feast is celebrated every 30th of May. The city is politically subdivided into 35 barangays; Alasas, Baliti, Bulaon, Calulut, Dela Paz Norte, Dela Paz Sur, Del Carmen, Del Pilar, Del Rosario, Dolores, Juliana, Lara, Lourdes, Maimpis, Magliman, Malino, Malpitic, Pandaras, Panipuan, Pulung Bulo, Santo Rosario (Pob.), Quebiawan, Saguin, San Agustin, San Felipe, San Isidro, San Jose, San Juan, San Nicolas, San Pedro Cutud, Santa Lucia, Santa Teresita, Santo Niño, Sindalan, and Telabastagan. Most of the barangays in San Fernando are named after Saints and plants/trees that are exclusively abundant to them.

Alasas was derived from tree alasa (Ficus ulmifolia Lam.)
Baliti is a simple term for strangling.
Bulaon was named after the bulaon tree that are know as lagundi in Guam and the molauin in filipino.
Del Pilar takes its name from the spanish that represent Mary of the Pillar of the Virgin Mary.
Del Rosario is a spanish surname that's also from the second element of a personal name formed with the religious suffic Del Rosario of the Rosary.
Dolores means sorrow or pain. It was derived from latin word dolor.
Juliana derived its name from Santa Juliana or from an unknown local resident.
Lara means cheerful and happy.
Lourdes is a reference to the Virgin Mary taken from a town in France.
Magliman is the verb used by an infanticipating women when she asked for a food as a favor.
Malino means clear as it is close to the headwaters.
Panipuan is derived from a conjugation of the rootword liman.
Pandaras was named after the adze-like tool daras that is used for making old canoe-type boat known to locals as balutu.
Santo Rosario is a latin noun rosarium that means rosegarden or garland of roses. In this case, it means rosary.
Saguin was named after the fruit.
San Jose was named by the people after their patron saint San Jose Labrador.
Santa Teresita may have derived its name from Santa Juliana.
San Nicolas was name after their patron saint San Nicolas Tolentino.
Santo Nino was named after Santo Nino de Cebu, a Roman Catholic Title of the Child Jesus.
Telabastagan can be the bestidor-like frame used in weaving fishing nets or dase ebus.

Unique Practices

Near relatives of a mother about to deliver a child in Guagua, Pampanga, along with their neighbors, create noise by screaming, banging tin cans, and exploding firecrackers in order to help push the fetus quicker.
The baby's baptismal gown is used as a souvenir and decoration for the sala (living room) in many Kapampangan homes. It is framed and hung like a portrait.
After the wake (makipaglame), everyone participates in the libing (interment) for at least three days and two nights. Vigil is held until the ninth day after the deceased's burial, known as pasiyam. On the first anniversary of a person's death, lukas paldas (literally, the removal of one's clothes for mourning) is observed with a lavish dinner. The pangadi (prayers) is an integral aspect of the ceremony. Kapampangans also exhibits numerous folklores such as the nuno (dwarves who resides in mounds), Mangkukulam (a person who posseses a dreadful evil power), tianaka (evil spirits who inhabit forests and bamboo thickets), dwende (spirit that assumes the form of man), Kapre (nocturnal giants), and magkukutud (beings that can separate their heads from their bodies).

Kapampangan Language

Kapampangan, also called Pampango, is ethnolinguistic group living in the Philippines, principally in the central plain of Luzon, especially in the province of Pampanga, but also in parts of other adjoining provinces. Kapampangans numbered some two million in the early 21st century. The Kapampangan language is closely related to others of the central Philippines which belongs to the Austronesian (Malayo-Polynesian) family of languages. The Kapampangan homeland, which used to extend north from Manila Bay, has a relatively high population density. Many Kapampangans are tenant farmers and landless workers. Artists of the group are mostly potters, jewelers, lantern makers, blacksmiths, and wood-carvers. Most Kapampangans are Christians, predominantly Roman Catholics.

Trivias

Longtime Pampanga Businesses

Pampanga have businesses that stood the test of time founded by people who poured their blood, sweat and tears to build this establishment. San Fernando’s “Apung Gari Bakery & Kiosk” established in 1955 by couple Jesusa “Susing” Quiambao and husband Jose “Pitong” Valencia. The name came from Susing’s mother, Magarita Quiambao known by managing the “La Satisfacion Bakery, Apung Gari”. One can enjoy different delicacies: Pancit Luglug (a best-seller), Arroz Caldo, Chicken Mami, Magnolia Ice Cream and Ice Cream Sundae. Halo-halo, Lumpiang Prito, Magnolia Milk. Assorted cakes and pies. Descendants continued its legacy even after the original owner’s death even it was eventually sold to the Santiago family around 2007 whom renamed the establishment into LBS (Leonila B. Santiago) Bakeshop and Kiosk.

Parul and the Giant San Fernando Lantern

Kapampangan’s have been creating all kinds of arts and crafts with their hands for the purposes of utilitarian and decorative functions (homes, word, leisure and religion). To name a few: Kuran at Pasu (Sto. Tomas), Gitara (Guagua), Burarul (Angeles), etc. San Fernando is known for their “Parul”. The industry owes its popularity to them who pioneered the evolution of this paper / wooden star lanterns for the “lubenes” (procession) to the giant kaleidoscopic lanterns which are present every December’s Giant Lantern Festival. Electricity gave rise to more innovation. One prolific figure is Rodolfo David whom used rotors to give the lanterns their amazing play of colors.

San Fernando’s Chief Justice

Pampanga have manage to produce notable figures including two Presidents (Diosdado Macapagal and Gloria Macapagal Arroyo). Born in San Fernando Pampanga, Jose Abad Santos was the fifth Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines whom served as Acting President of the Philippines during World War II. He became Chief Justice on December 24, 1941, shortly after the outbreak of World War II. Known by his famous quote address to his son during his execution under Japanese Custody due to his refusal to cooperate. "Do not cry, Pepito, show to these people that you are brave. It is an honor to die for one's country. Not everybody has that chance".

Religious Practices

Kapampangan’s are known to be deeply religious. Most are devout Catholics, thus they take their religiosity to the extreme sometimes. One of such actions happens in the City of San Fernando Pampanga, Barangay San Pedro Cutud. The San Pedro Cutud Lenten Rites is a Holy Week (Good Friday) re-enactment of Christ’s Passion and Death where it includes a passion play where at least three penitents are nailed to wooden crosses atop a makeshift Calvary though this practice is not recommended by religious leaders in the country the is still attended routinely by many Catholics all over the world.

Creation Myth from Kapampangans

A long, long time ago, the universe was full of gods and goddesses. Of all these gods there existed one supreme god by the name of Mangechay. He ruled the universe for several millenniums with great power. These gods lived in the different planets, and their common temple was suspended in the air. These planets were far apart. It took hundreds of years to go from one planet to another. The great god who ruled over them lived in the sun and his bride lived in the moon. Their daughter lived in a planet called after her name (presumably Venus). The supreme god sent for all his vassals to meet in great council to decide on a certain affair in the universe. The gods responded to the call and the elements were disturbed greatly by the swiftness of their chariots. As soon as they gazed at the beautiful daughter of Mangechay who was seated on her golden chair the gods were charmed at her beauty. Instead of deciding on the affair of the universe, the gods proposed marriage to the pretty goddess. The great god was troubled and did not know on whom he should confer the hand of his daughter. Finally he decided that the question was to be settled by combat. The gods returned to their respective abodes and made the necessary preparations. The encounter lasted for several thousand years and nearly all the gods perished. During the battle the daughter of Mangechay died and consequently the trouble ended. The great god, after the combat, looked down and saw the earth of today to his great surprise. The earth was formed by the great masses of stones used in the fight.
